Escaping Saddle Points in Heterogeneous Federated Learning
via Distributed SGD with Communication Compression

Sijin Chen
Princeton Princeton University; email: chensj@princeton.edu. ‚ÄÉ‚ÄÉ Zhize Li
CMU Carnegie Mellon University; emails: {zhizeli, yuejiechi}@cmu.edu. ‚ÄÉ‚ÄÉ Yuejie Chi22footnotemark: 2
CMU
Abstract

We consider the problem of finding second-order stationary points of heterogeneous federated learning (FL). Previous works in FL mostly focus on first-order convergence guarantees, which do not rule out the scenario of unstable saddle points. Meanwhile, it is a key bottleneck of FL to achieve communication efficiency without compensating the learning accuracy, especially when local data are highly heterogeneous across different clients. Given this, we propose a novel algorithm Power-EF that only communicates compressed information via a novel error-feedback scheme. To our knowledge, Power-EF is the first distributed and compressed SGD algorithm that provably escapes saddle points in heterogeneous FL without any data homogeneity assumptions. In particular, Power-EF improves to second-order stationary points after visiting first-order (possibly saddle) points, using additional gradient queries and communication rounds only of almost the same order required by first-order convergence, and the convergence rate exhibits a linear speedup in terms of the number of workers. Our theory improves/recovers previous results, while extending to much more tolerant settings on the local data. Numerical experiments are provided to complement the theory.

Keywords: distributed SGD, heterogeneous federated learning, communication compression, second-order convergence

1 Introduction

The prevalence of large-scale data and enormous model size in modern machine learning problems give rise to an increasing interest in distributed machine learning, where a number of clients cooperate to handle the extremely heavy computation in the learning task without the need to move data around.

We consider a distributed server-client setting. Suppose that each client i‚àà[n]ùëñdelimited-[]ùëõi\in[n] has access to a local dataset ùí≤(i)superscriptùí≤ùëñ\mathcal{W}^{(i)} distributed over an unknown space Œ©Œ©\Omega, and a central server maintains a model parameterized by ùíô‚àà‚Ñùdùíôsuperscript‚Ñùùëë\bm{x}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}. Given a cost function F:‚Ñùd√óŒ©‚Üí‚Ñù:ùêπ‚Üísuperscript‚ÑùùëëŒ©‚ÑùF:\mathbb{R}^{d}\times\Omega\to\mathbb{R} that evaluates the performance of a model ùíôùíô\bm{x} on an input data sample œâ‚ààŒ©ùúîŒ©\omega\in\Omega, the iùëñi-th local objective function fisubscriptùëìùëñf_{i} is defined by fi‚Äã(ùíô):=ùîºœâ(i)‚àºùí≤(i)‚Äã[F‚Äã(ùíô,œâ(i))].assignsubscriptùëìùëñùíôsubscriptùîºsimilar-tosuperscriptùúîùëñsuperscriptùí≤ùëñdelimited-[]ùêπùíôsuperscriptùúîùëñf_{i}(\bm{x}):=\mathbb{E}_{\omega^{(i)}\sim\mathcal{W}^{(i)}}[F(\bm{x},\omega^{(i)})]. We would like to find a model parameter ùíôùíô\bm{x} that minimizes the local objectives in an averaged manner, which leads to a finite-sum minimization problem:

minùíô‚àà‚Ñùd‚Å°f‚Äã(ùíô):=1n‚Äã‚àëi=1nfi‚Äã(ùíô),assignsubscriptùíôsuperscript‚Ñùùëëùëìùíô1ùëõsuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëõsubscriptùëìùëñùíô\displaystyle\min_{\bm{x}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}}f(\bm{x}):=\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}f_{i}(\bm{x}), (1)

where the local objective functions {fi}i=1nsuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptùëìùëñùëñ1ùëõ\{f_{i}\}_{i=1}^{n} and the global objective function f=1n‚Äã‚àëi=1nfiùëì1ùëõsuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëõsubscriptùëìùëñf=\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}f_{i} are in general nonconvex, especially in machine learning applications.

Heterogeneous federated learning.

Assumptions on data homogeneity across the clients can be deployed to underplay this problem to a certain extent, since intuitively, there are less disagreements across the local objectives to reconcile. For example, each local dataset ùí≤(i)superscriptùí≤ùëñ\mathcal{W}^{(i)} may take similar distributions, or may be uploaded to a data center that maintains global knowledge (Koneƒçn√Ω et¬†al.,, 2016). However, in many real applications such as Internet of Things (IoT) (Savazzi et¬†al.,, 2020; Nguyen et¬†al.,, 2021), smart healthcare (Xu et¬†al.,, 2021), and networked model devices (Kang et¬†al.,, 2020), such assumptions become impractical in that local datasets display a strongly heterogeneous pattern, while they should not be exchanged or exposed to a third party due to privacy sensitivity or communication infeasibility (Koneƒçn√Ω et¬†al.,, 2016). These thorny scenarios of data heterogeneity correspond to a framework for distributed learning, namely federated learning (FL) (Kairouz et¬†al.,, 2019), which is now accumulating special attention from both academia and industry. The heterogeneous data constitute a major challenge in the distributed optimization problem under federated settings, which we refer to as heterogeneous FL.

Distributed SGD with communication compression.

A prevalent approach to solve (1) is by distributed stochastic gradient descent (SGD) (Koloskova et¬†al.,, 2020), a family of algorithms following the essential idea that each client computes its local stochastic gradient and then sends the gradient (or a carefully designed surrogate for the gradient) to the central server for parameter update. Distributed SGD has to take good care of communication efficiency: due to the large client number nùëõn (Savazzi et¬†al.,, 2020) and model scale dùëëd (Brown et¬†al.,, 2020) in modern machine learning tasks, the communication cost from the clients to the server becomes the main bottleneck of optimization. Moreover, many resource constraints in real communication systems, such as limited bandwidth and stringent delay requirements, also highlight the importance of establishing efficient communication for the distributed training procedure.

A natural method to attain communication efficiency is (lossy) compression: one can deploy a compressor ùíû:‚Ñùd‚Üí‚Ñùd:ùíû‚Üísuperscript‚Ñùùëësuperscript‚Ñùùëë\mathcal{C}:\mathbb{R}^{d}\to\mathbb{R}^{d} in distributed SGD, which compresses any message ùíô‚àà‚Ñùdùíôsuperscript‚Ñùùëë\bm{x}\in\mathbb{R}^{d} the client would like to send to the server, so that the traffic ùíû‚Äã(ùíô)ùíûùíô\mathcal{C}(\bm{x}) takes up a smaller bandwidth. In literature, a randomized operator ùíû:‚Ñùd‚Üí‚Ñùd:ùíû‚Üísuperscript‚Ñùùëësuperscript‚Ñùùëë\mathcal{C}:\mathbb{R}^{d}\to\mathbb{R}^{d} is said to be a Œºùúá\mu-compressor if the (expected) relative distortion of the compressed output is bounded by Œºùúá\mu (Stich et¬†al.,, 2018; Richt√°rik et¬†al.,, 2021; Fatkhullin et¬†al.,, 2021; Huang et¬†al.,, 2022), which helps quantify the information loss due to compression.

Motivation.

It has been a recent interest to establish convergence results for distributed SGD with communication compression. Many among these works (Stich et¬†al.,, 2018; Koloskova et¬†al., 2019a, ; Xie et¬†al.,, 2020; Avdiukhin and Yaroslavtsev,, 2021; Huang et¬†al.,, 2022) assume bounded local gradients ‚Äñ‚àáfi‚Äã(ùíô)‚Äñ2‚â§G2superscriptnorm‚àásubscriptùëìùëñùíô2superscriptùê∫2\left\|{\nabla f_{i}(\bm{x})}\right\|^{2}\leq G^{2}, or bounded dissimilarity of local gradients 1n‚Äã‚Äñ‚àëi=1n‚àáfi‚Äã(ùíô)‚àí‚àáf‚Äã(ùíô)‚Äñ2‚â§G21ùëõsuperscriptnormsuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëõ‚àásubscriptùëìùëñùíô‚àáùëìùíô2superscriptùê∫2\frac{1}{n}\left\|{\sum_{i=1}^{n}\nabla f_{i}(\bm{x})-\nabla f(\bm{x})}\right\|^{2}\leq G^{2}, reflecting a reliance on data homogeneity that fails to hold in heterogeneous FL. Another body of the works (Richt√°rik et¬†al.,, 2021; Fatkhullin et¬†al.,, 2021; Richt√°rik et¬†al.,, 2022; Zhao et¬†al.,, 2022), although allowing heterogeneous data, only ensures first-order optimality, i.e. convergence to an œµitalic-œµ\epsilon-optimal first-order stationary point ùíôùíô\bm{x} with ‚Äñ‚àáf‚Äã(ùíô)‚Äñ‚â§œµnorm‚àáùëìùíôitalic-œµ\left\|{\nabla f(\bm{x})}\right\|\leq\epsilon, which does not suffice to justify the goodness of the solution in the nonconvex setting where saddle points are abundant and do not necessarily lead to generalizable performance (Dauphin et¬†al.,, 2014). It is then important to obtain second-order convergence guarantees that ensure the algorithm escapes the saddle points and converges to an œµitalic-œµ\epsilon-optimal second-order stationary point, with an additional control on the Hessian positive-definiteness that says ‚àíŒªmin‚Äã(‚àá2f‚Äã(ùíô))‚â§O‚Äã(œµ)subscriptùúÜsuperscript‚àá2ùëìùíôùëÇitalic-œµ-\lambda_{\min}(\nabla^{2}f(\bm{x}))\leq O\left(\sqrt{\epsilon}\right). Despite the growing literature of saddle-point escaping algorithms in the centralized setting (Jin et¬†al.,, 2021; Ge et¬†al.,, 2015; Li,, 2019; Daneshmand et¬†al.,, 2018), to the best of our knowledge, no existing distributed SGD algorithms succeed with second-order guarantees in the presence of both communication compression and data heterogeneity. In summary, the current research sparked a natural question as the primary concern of this paper:

On heterogeneous data, is there a distributed SGD algorithm with communication compression that attains second-order convergence guarantees for nonconvex problems?

1.1 Our contribution

To the best of our knowledge, this work is the first to answer the above question affirmatively. Our specific contributions are as follows.

  • ‚Ä¢

    A novel error-feedback mechanism: we propose Power-EF, a new distributed SGD algorithm that contains a novel error-feedback mechanism for communication compression.

  • ‚Ä¢

    First-order convergence: we prove that, with high probability, Power-EF converges to œµitalic-œµ\epsilon-optimal first-order stationary points within O~‚Äã(1n‚Äãœµ4+1Œº1.5‚Äãœµ3)~ùëÇ1ùëõsuperscriptitalic-œµ41superscriptùúá1.5superscriptitalic-œµ3\tilde{O}\left(\frac{1}{n\epsilon^{4}}+\frac{1}{\mu^{1.5}\epsilon^{3}}\right) stochastic gradient queries and communication rounds. The algorithm shows a linear speedup pattern in that the convergence rate benefits with the increase of the number of workers nùëõn.

  • ‚Ä¢

    Second-order convergence: we prove that, with high probability, Power-EF escapes the saddle points and converges to œµitalic-œµ\epsilon-optimal second-order stationary points within O~‚Äã(1n‚Äãœµ4+1Œº1.5‚Äãœµ3+Œº‚Äãn+1Œº3‚Äãœµ2.5)~ùëÇ1ùëõsuperscriptitalic-œµ41superscriptùúá1.5superscriptitalic-œµ3ùúáùëõ1superscriptùúá3superscriptitalic-œµ2.5\tilde{O}\left(\frac{1}{n\epsilon^{4}}+\frac{1}{\mu^{1.5}\epsilon^{3}}+\frac{\mu n+1}{\mu^{3}\epsilon^{2.5}}\right) stochastic gradient queries and communication rounds. This suggests that Power-EF finds second-order stationary points with almost the same order of gradient and communication complexities as it takes to for first-order convergence.

  • ‚Ä¢

    Convergence under arbitrary data heterogeneity: importantly, the theory of Power-EF does not require assumptions on data similarity between different clients, thus allowing arbitrary heterogeneity in federated learning tasks.

See also Table 1 and 2 for a detailed comparison between our proposed method and existing algorithms.

1.2 Related works

Communication compression.

A communication operator, or a compressor, is deployed to reduce the communication cost in distributed SGD. Various instances of compressors include Quantized SGD (Alistarh et¬†al.,, 2017) that rounds real-valued gradient vectors to discrete buckets, Sign SGD (Bernstein et¬†al.,, 2018) that represents the gradient with the sign of each coordinate, Top-kùëòk (Stich et¬†al.,, 2018) that selects kùëòk coordinates out of the total dimension dùëëd with the largest magnitudes, and Random-kùëòk (Stich et¬†al.,, 2018) that performs the above selection uniformly at random, among others. Regardless of the specific design, a general biased compressor is characterized by a parameter Œº‚àà(0,1]ùúá01\mu\in(0,1] that controls the aforementioned distortion of the operator.

With a compressor at hand, one also needs a mechanism that specifies what message should be compressed and transmitted between clients. A naive, prototypical mechanism is to directly replace the gradient with its compressed version and then conduct the update step as what is done in regular SGD, for example ùíôt+1=ùíôt‚àíŒ∑‚ãÖùíû‚Äã(‚àá~‚Äãf‚Äã(ùíôt))subscriptùíôùë°1subscriptùíôùë°‚ãÖùúÇùíû~‚àáùëìsubscriptùíôùë°\bm{x}_{t+1}=\bm{x}_{t}-\eta\cdot\mathcal{C}(\tilde{\nabla}f(\bm{x}_{t})) or its momentum variants. This mechanism underpins Alistarh et¬†al., (2017); Bernstein et¬†al., (2018), among others. However, error may accumulate in this simple replacement due to the lossy compression and menace its convergence. Various works propose new mechanisms to properly handle the error to boost the convergence performance, including Error-Feedback (Seide et¬†al.,, 2014; Stich et¬†al.,, 2018; Karimireddy et¬†al.,, 2019; Avdiukhin and Yaroslavtsev,, 2021; Li et¬†al.,, 2022) and its variants (Richt√°rik et¬†al.,, 2021; Fatkhullin et¬†al.,, 2021; Huang et¬†al.,, 2022), with adaptations to decentralized optimization (Koloskova et¬†al., 2019a, ; Koloskova et¬†al., 2019b, ; Zhao et¬†al.,, 2022). Most of the works guarantee first-order convergence subject to different levels of assumptions on data homogeneity, cf. Tables 1 and 2.

Second-order convergence of gradient methods.

It is well-known that gradient methods converge to first-order stationary points (Nesterov,, 2004). In non-convex problems, however, first-order convergence can be easily attacked by saddle points that may trap the GD trajectory. It is therefore important to investigate whether the algorithm is capable of escaping saddle points and converging to second-order stationary points. Asymptotically, Lee et¬†al., (2016) proved that GD with random initialization converges to a local minimum almost surely. However, the algorithm may still have to take an exponential time to escape the saddle points (Du et¬†al.,, 2017).

As to the polynomial-time guarantees, it is known that perturbing the gradient with isotropic noise helps GD converge to local minimizers (Ge et¬†al.,, 2015; Jin et¬†al.,, 2017). The perturbation technique gives rise to similar guarantees for other gradient methods, from SGD (Jin et¬†al.,, 2021) to SVRG (Ge et¬†al.,, 2019) and stochastic recursive gradient descent (Li,, 2019). On the other hand, instead of gradient perturbation, Daneshmand et¬†al., (2018) establishes the saddle-escaping property of SGD under an additional Correlated Negative Curvature (CNC) assumption regarding the statistical property of the stochastic gradient oracle.

Recently, Avdiukhin and Yaroslavtsev, (2021) leverages the perturbation technique to analyze the second-order stationarity of SGD with communication compression. The derivation is based on single-node implementation, which does not directly extend to the distributed settings. Further, it requires a conditional reset procedure in each iteration to achieve second-order convergence, at the expense of high communication cost as the server has to collect and maintain the local error terms using an uncompressed channel. Therefore, it remains obscure if the results therein still apply to the distributed setting with communication efficiency demands.

2 Problem Formulation

This paper is concerned with solving the nonconvex finite-sum minimization problem in a federated setting, while each client should only query a local stochastic gradient oracle, and communicate their information with the server in an efficient manner using compression. We detail this formulation in the following.

2.1 Nonconvex finite-sum minimization

Recall that we consider a federated optimization problem of finding an optimal parameter ùíôùíô\bm{x} to minimize the local objectives {fi}i=1nsuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptùëìùëñùëñ1ùëõ\{f_{i}\}_{i=1}^{n} in an averaged manner, which is stated as an unconstrained finite-sum minimization problem:

minùíô‚àà‚Ñùd‚Å°f‚Äã(ùíô):=1n‚Äã‚àëi=1nfi‚Äã(ùíô),assignsubscriptùíôsuperscript‚Ñùùëëùëìùíô1ùëõsuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëõsubscriptùëìùëñùíô\displaystyle\min_{\bm{x}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}}f(\bm{x}):=\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}f_{i}(\bm{x}),

where {fi}i=1nsuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptùëìùëñùëñ1ùëõ\{f_{i}\}_{i=1}^{n}‚Äôs are the local objective functions, and nùëõn is the number of clients.

We focus on the case where the objective functions are nonconvex, subject to the following assumptions.

Assumption 2.1.

There exists some fmin>‚àí‚àûsubscriptùëìf_{\min}>-\infty such that f‚Äã(ùê±)‚â•fminùëìùê±subscriptùëìf(\bm{x})\geq f_{\min} for all ùê±‚àà‚Ñùdùê±superscript‚Ñùùëë\bm{x}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}.

We will leverage the boundedness in Assumption 2.1 to establish first-order convergence results. For second-order results, similar to Avdiukhin and Yaroslavtsev, (2021), the following alternative is required.

Assumption 2.1*.

There exists some fmax<‚àûsubscriptùëìf_{\max}<\infty such that |f‚Äã(ùê±1)‚àíf‚Äã(ùê±2)|‚â§fmaxùëìsubscriptùê±1ùëìsubscriptùê±2subscriptùëì|f(\bm{x}_{1})-f(\bm{x}_{2})|\leq f_{\max} for all ùê±1,ùê±2‚àà‚Ñùdsubscriptùê±1subscriptùê±2superscript‚Ñùùëë\bm{x}_{1},\bm{x}_{2}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}.

Besides boundedness, we also assume the smoothness of fùëìf.

Assumption 2.2.

fùëìf is differentiable and LùêøL-smooth, i.e.

‚Äñ‚àáf‚Äã(ùíô1)‚àí‚àáf‚Äã(ùíô2)‚Äñ‚â§L‚Äã‚Äñùíô1‚àíùíô2‚Äñ,‚àÄùíô1,ùíô2‚àà‚Ñùd.formulae-sequencenorm‚àáùëìsubscriptùíô1‚àáùëìsubscriptùíô2ùêønormsubscriptùíô1subscriptùíô2for-allsubscriptùíô1subscriptùíô2superscript‚Ñùùëë\left\|{\nabla f(\bm{x}_{1})-\nabla f(\bm{x}_{2})}\right\|\leq L\left\|{\bm{x}_{1}-\bm{x}_{2}}\right\|,\quad\forall\bm{x}_{1},\bm{x}_{2}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}.

In the same spirit as what we do for the boundedness assumption, we need to further assume a Lipschitz property of the Hessian to prove second-order results.

Assumption 2.3.

fùëìf is twice differentiable and œÅùúå\rho-Hessian Lipschitz, i.e.,

‚Äñ‚àá2f‚Äã(ùíô1)‚àí‚àá2f‚Äã(ùíô2)‚Äñ‚â§œÅ‚Äã‚Äñùíô1‚àíùíô2‚Äñ,‚àÄùíô1,ùíô2‚àà‚Ñùd.formulae-sequencenormsuperscript‚àá2ùëìsubscriptùíô1superscript‚àá2ùëìsubscriptùíô2ùúånormsubscriptùíô1subscriptùíô2for-allsubscriptùíô1subscriptùíô2superscript‚Ñùùëë\left\|{\nabla^{2}f(\bm{x}_{1})-\nabla^{2}f(\bm{x}_{2})}\right\|\leq\rho\left\|{\bm{x}_{1}-\bm{x}_{2}}\right\|,\quad\forall\bm{x}_{1},\bm{x}_{2}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}.

We emphasize that no assumption is made on the boundedness of, or similarity between, the local gradients.

2.2 Local stochastic gradient oracle

Each client iùëñi is allowed to query a local stochastic gradient oracle ‚àá~‚Äãfi~‚àásubscriptùëìùëñ\tilde{\nabla}f_{i}.

Assumption 2.4.

Each ‚àá~‚Äãfi~‚àásubscriptùëìùëñ\tilde{\nabla}f_{i} is L~isubscript~ùêøùëñ\tilde{L}_{i}-Lipschitz, i.e.

‚Äñ‚àá~‚Äãfi‚Äã(ùíô1)‚àí‚àá~‚Äãfi‚Äã(ùíô2)‚Äñ‚â§L~i‚Äã‚Äñùíô1‚àíùíô2‚Äñ,‚àÄùíô1,ùíô2‚àà‚Ñùd.formulae-sequencenorm~‚àásubscriptùëìùëñsubscriptùíô1~‚àásubscriptùëìùëñsubscriptùíô2subscript~ùêøùëñnormsubscriptùíô1subscriptùíô2for-allsubscriptùíô1subscriptùíô2superscript‚Ñùùëë\displaystyle\left\|{\tilde{\nabla}f_{i}(\bm{x}_{1})-\tilde{\nabla}f_{i}(\bm{x}_{2})}\right\|\leq\tilde{L}_{i}\left\|{\bm{x}_{1}-\bm{x}_{2}}\right\|,\quad\forall\bm{x}_{1},\bm{x}_{2}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}.

Based on Assumption 2.4, it is straightforward to verify that the global stochastic gradient ‚àá~‚Äãf~‚àáùëì\tilde{\nabla}f is L~~ùêø\tilde{L}-smooth with L~:=1n‚Äã‚àëi=1nL~i2assign~ùêø1ùëõsuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëõsuperscriptsubscript~ùêøùëñ2\tilde{L}:=\sqrt{\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}\tilde{L}_{i}^{2}}.

Besides smoothness, the stochastic gradients should also approximate the true gradients.

Assumption 2.5.

For any ùê±‚àà‚Ñùdùê±superscript‚Ñùùëë\bm{x}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}, the mutually independent stochastic gradient oracles ‚àá~‚Äãfi~‚àásubscriptùëìùëñ\tilde{\nabla}f_{i} satisfy

ùîº‚Äã[‚àá~‚Äãfi‚Äã(ùíô)]ùîºdelimited-[]~‚àásubscriptùëìùëñùíô\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\left[\tilde{\nabla}f_{i}(\bm{x})\right] =‚àáfi‚Äã(ùíô),absent‚àásubscriptùëìùëñùíô\displaystyle=\nabla f_{i}(\bm{x}),
Pr‚Å°(‚Äñ‚àá~‚Äãfi‚Äã(ùíô)‚àí‚àáfi‚Äã(ùíô)‚Äñ‚â•t)Prnorm~‚àásubscriptùëìùëñùíô‚àásubscriptùëìùëñùíôùë°\displaystyle\Pr\left(\left\|{\tilde{\nabla}f_{i}(\bm{x})-\nabla f_{i}(\bm{x})}\right\|\geq t\right) ‚â§2‚Äãexp‚Å°(‚àít22‚ÄãœÉ2)absent2superscriptùë°22superscriptùúé2\displaystyle\leq 2\exp\left(-\frac{t^{2}}{2\sigma^{2}}\right)

for all t‚â•0ùë°0t\geq 0 and some œÉ>0ùúé0\sigma>0.

Assumption 2.5 is a high-probability variant of the commonly-used bounded variance assumption, stated in expectation. Switching to such a high-probability variant is again necessary for second-order analysis (Jin et¬†al.,, 2021; Li,, 2019) because we aim at a convergence guarantee with probability bounds.

Additionally, we introduce the mini-batch version of the stochastic gradient. For integer kùëòk, let ‚àá~‚Äãfi‚Äã(ùíô)(1)~‚àásubscriptùëìùëñsuperscriptùíô1\tilde{\nabla}f_{i}(\bm{x})^{(1)}, ‚Ä¶‚Ä¶\ldots, ‚àá~‚Äãfi‚Äã(ùíô)(k)~‚àásubscriptùëìùëñsuperscriptùíôùëò\tilde{\nabla}f_{i}(\bm{x})^{(k)} be the kùëòk independent queries to the stochastic oracle at ùíôùíô\bm{x}. The mini-batch gradient is defined as their average, i.e. ‚àá~k‚Äãfi‚Äã(ùíô)=1k‚Äã‚àëj=1k‚àá~‚Äãfi‚Äã(ùíô)(j)subscript~‚àáùëòsubscriptùëìùëñùíô1ùëòsuperscriptsubscriptùëó1ùëò~‚àásubscriptùëìùëñsuperscriptùíôùëó\tilde{\nabla}_{k}f_{i}(\bm{x})=\frac{1}{k}\sum_{j=1}^{k}\tilde{\nabla}f_{i}(\bm{x})^{(j)}.

2.3 Communication compression

To enable efficient communication over bandwidth-limited scenarios, our setting requests that the communication between the clients and the server should be compressed according to a possibly randomized scheme ùíûùíû\mathcal{C}. Specifically, for any input ùíô‚àà‚Ñùdùíôsuperscript‚Ñùùëë\bm{x}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}, the scheme outputs a surrogate ùíû‚Äã(ùíô)‚àà‚Ñùdùíûùíôsuperscript‚Ñùùëë\mathcal{C}(\bm{x})\in\mathbb{R}^{d} so that the transmission of ùíû‚Äã(ùíô)ùíûùíô\mathcal{C}(\bm{x}) between machines would take up a smaller bandwidth than the direct transmission of ùíôùíô\bm{x}.

Definition 2.6.

A possibly random mapping ùíû:‚Ñùd‚Üí‚Ñùd:ùíû‚Üísuperscript‚Ñùùëësuperscript‚Ñùùëë\mathcal{C}:\mathbb{R}^{d}\to\mathbb{R}^{d} is said to be a Œºùúá\mu-compressor for some Œº‚àà(0,1]ùúá01\mu\in(0,1] if

‚Äñùíô‚àíùíû‚Äã(ùíô)‚Äñ2‚â§(1‚àíŒº)‚Äã‚Äñùíô‚Äñ2,‚àÄùíô‚àà‚Ñùd.formulae-sequencesuperscriptnormùíôùíûùíô21ùúásuperscriptnormùíô2for-allùíôsuperscript‚Ñùùëë\left\|{\bm{x}-\mathcal{C}(\bm{x})}\right\|^{2}\leq(1-\mu)\left\|{\bm{x}}\right\|^{2},\quad\forall\bm{x}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}.

Definition 2.6 slightly deviates from the conventional definition that controls the expected distortion, i.e., ùîº‚Äã[‚Äñùíô‚àíùíû‚Äã(ùíô)‚Äñ2]‚â§(1‚àíŒº)‚Äã‚Äñùíô‚Äñ2ùîºdelimited-[]superscriptnormùíôùíûùíô21ùúásuperscriptnormùíô2\mathbb{E}[\left\|{\bm{x}-\mathcal{C}(\bm{x})}\right\|^{2}]\leq(1-\mu)\left\|{\bm{x}}\right\|^{2}, to facilitate the derivation of high-probability results. Examples of compressors that satisfy Definition 2.6 include Top-kùëòk (Stich et¬†al.,, 2018) and a family of compressors named general biased rounding (Beznosikov et¬†al.,, 2020).

3 Proposed Algorithm

This section introduces our proposed algorithm Power-EF that is suitable to heterogeneous FL with communication compression.

3.1 Fast Compressed Communication

We first introduce the Fast Compressed Communication (FCC) module proposed by Huang et¬†al., (2022), which is deployed at each client in their compressed SGD algorithm NEOLITHIC. For input ùíô‚àà‚Ñùdùíôsuperscript‚Ñùùëë\bm{x}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}, the FCC module with parameter p‚àà‚Ñ§+ùëùsubscript‚Ñ§p\in\mathbb{Z}_{+} recursively computes the residual {ùíói}i=1psuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptùíóùëñùëñ1ùëù\{\bm{v}_{i}\}_{i=1}^{p} for pùëùp rounds, where

ùíó1=ùíô;ùíói=ùíô‚àí‚àëj=1i‚àí1ùíû‚Äã(ùíój),i=2,‚Ä¶,p.formulae-sequencesubscriptùíó1ùíôformulae-sequencesubscriptùíóùëñùíôsuperscriptsubscriptùëó1ùëñ1ùíûsubscriptùíóùëóùëñ2‚Ä¶ùëù\bm{v}_{1}=\bm{x};\quad\bm{v}_{i}=\bm{x}-\sum_{j=1}^{i-1}\mathcal{C}(\bm{v}_{j}),\quad i=2,...,p.

It then outputs FCCp‚Äã(ùíô)=‚àëi=1pùíû‚Äã(ùíói)subscriptFCCùëùùíôsuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëùùíûsubscriptùíóùëñ\mathrm{FCC}_{p}(\bm{x})=\sum_{i=1}^{p}\mathcal{C}(\bm{v}_{i}). To transmit the output to the server efficiently, the client transmits the set of compressed vectors {ùíû‚Äã(ùíói)}i=1psuperscriptsubscriptùíûsubscriptùíóùëñùëñ1ùëù\{\mathcal{C}(\bm{v}_{i})\}_{i=1}^{p} through the channel, and the exact output is assembled by summation on the server side.

Defining ùíü:ùíô‚Ü¶ùíô‚àíùíû‚Äã(ùíô):ùíümaps-toùíôùíôùíûùíô\mathcal{D}:\bm{x}\mapsto\bm{x}-\mathcal{C}(\bm{x}), one can observe that FCCp‚Äã(ùíô)=ùíô‚àíùíüp‚Äã(ùíô)subscriptFCCùëùùíôùíôsuperscriptùíüùëùùíô\mathrm{FCC}_{p}(\bm{x})=\bm{x}-\mathcal{D}^{p}(\bm{x}). In fact, the FCC module is able to refine the compression loss by harnessing the contraction property of ùíüùíü\mathcal{D}. Specifically, ùíüùíü\mathcal{D} is a contraction because ‚Äñùíü‚Äã(ùíô)‚Äñ2‚â§(1‚àíŒº)‚Äã‚Äñùíô‚Äñ2superscriptnormùíüùíô21ùúásuperscriptnormùíô2\left\|{\mathcal{D}(\bm{x})}\right\|^{2}\leq(1-\mu)\left\|{\bm{x}}\right\|^{2} due to Definition 2.6. Hence, the error of the FCC module ‚Äñùíô‚àíFCCp‚Äã(ùíô)‚Äñ2‚â§(1‚àíŒº)p‚Äã‚Äñùíô‚Äñ2superscriptnormùíôsubscriptFCCùëùùíô2superscript1ùúáùëùsuperscriptnormùíô2\left\|{\bm{x}-\mathrm{FCC}_{p}(\bm{x})}\right\|^{2}\leq(1-\mu)^{p}\left\|{\bm{x}}\right\|^{2} enjoys a geometric decay with pùëùp.

3.2 Power-EF

We integrate the FCC module into our algorithm Power-EF, as summarized in Algorithm 1. The algorithm takes as input an initial model ùíô0subscriptùíô0\bm{x}_{0}, step size Œ∑ùúÇ\eta, FCC parameter pùëùp, perturbation radius rùëür, and the number of iterations TùëáT. After a simple initialization procedure, Power-EF iteratively produces a sequence {ùíôt}t=0Tsuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptùíôùë°ùë°0ùëá\{\bm{x}_{t}\}_{t=0}^{T} to gradually update the initial model by SGD-type descent. In each iteration, we use the accumulated gradient ‚àá~p‚Äãfisubscript~‚àáùëùsubscriptùëìùëñ\tilde{\nabla}_{p}f_{i} to balance the number of communication rounds and stochastic gradient complexity. Each iteration of Power-EF contains four conceptual stages interpreted as follows.

  • ‚Ä¢

    Feedback the local gradient estimate. We intend to use ùíÜt(i)superscriptsubscriptùíÜùë°ùëñ\bm{e}_{t}^{(i)}, the error up to the last iteration, to feedback our estimate of the local gradient ùíàt(i)superscriptsubscriptùíàùë°ùëñ\bm{g}_{t}^{(i)} for the current round. Firstly, based on the error, the client invokes FCC module to compute the feedback term ùíòt(i)+ùíÑt(i)superscriptsubscriptùíòùë°ùëñsuperscriptsubscriptùíÑùë°ùëñ\bm{w}_{t}^{(i)}+\bm{c}_{t}^{(i)} (Line 9‚Äì10). Then each client iùëñi gets its current gradient estimate ùíàt(i)superscriptsubscriptùíàùë°ùëñ\bm{g}_{t}^{(i)} by complementing the existing estimate ùíàt‚àí1(i)superscriptsubscriptùíàùë°1ùëñ\bm{g}_{t-1}^{(i)} with the feedback term (Line 11).

  • ‚Ä¢

    Update the error. Upon completion of the feedback, we increase the error term by the discrepancy between the real stochastic gradient (after artificial perturbation) and our local estimate ùíàt(i)superscriptsubscriptùíàùë°ùëñ\bm{g}_{t}^{(i)} (Line 12). In this way, the error term essentially stores the cumulative estimation discrepancy of ùíàt(i)superscriptsubscriptùíàùë°ùëñ\bm{g}_{t}^{(i)}, which is ready for feedback again on the next run.

  • ‚Ä¢

    Prepare the global gradient estimate. The update of global gradient estimate is conducted on a par with the local update method in an averaged manner (Line 16), so that we always have ùíàt=1n‚Äã‚àëi=1nùíàt(i)subscriptùíàùë°1ùëõsuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëõsuperscriptsubscriptùíàùë°ùëñ\bm{g}_{t}=\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}\bm{g}_{t}^{(i)}.

  • ‚Ä¢

    Update the model. Finally, the server updates the current model ùíôtsubscriptùíôùë°\bm{x}_{t} by a descending step along our global gradient estimate ùíàtsubscriptùíàùë°\bm{g}_{t} (Line¬†17).

3.3 Discussion

At its core, Power-EF benefits from the power contraction underlying the FCC module to upgrade the classical error-feedback mechanism (Avdiukhin and Yaroslavtsev,, 2021; Stich et¬†al.,, 2018), hence the name. Specifically, our algorithm inherits the classical design of error term to track the cumulative discrepancy of gradient estimation (Line 12), but refines the way errors are used to feedback the current gradient estimation by the FCC module. Moreover, while still guaranteeing second-order results, Power-EF manages to remove from the prior work (Avdiukhin and Yaroslavtsev,, 2021) an expensive procedure of conditinal reset that inevitably occupies the uncompressed bandwidth.

Data heterogeneity.

Mathematically, our mechanism is able to induce an error term recurrence irrelavent to local gradients, thus circumventing from data similarity assumptions. This favorable property originates from our design of Power-EF, which is nontrivially different from the existing NEOLITHIC (Huang et¬†al.,, 2022) algorithm where FCC module also plays a part. For example, NEOLITHIC inputs the gradient estimate to FCC while we input the estimation discrepancy, and error terms are also computed distinctly. As a notable result, contrary to our algorithm, the theory of NEOLITHIC still has to assume local gradient similarity.

Gradient perturbation.

We add an isotropic Gaussian noise to each stochastic gradient to help the model escape from saddle points. Intuitively, around saddle points, the isotropic perturbation ensures that the SGD trajectory can traverse a sufficient distance along the descending direction, i.e. the eigenvector of Hessian ‚àá2f‚Äã(ùíôt)superscript‚àá2ùëìsubscriptùíôùë°\nabla^{2}f(\bm{x}_{t}) with a negative eigenvalue, thus escaping the saddle region and gaining an objective decrease. The perturbation is not required for first-order convergence, in which case one can safely set r=0ùëü0r=0.

4 Performance Guarantees

In this section, we state the theoretical guarantees for Power-EF, where the proofs are deferred to the appendix. To begin, we first define the first-order and second-order approximate stationarity conditions.

Definition 4.1.

ùíô‚àà‚Ñùdùíôsuperscript‚Ñùùëë\bm{x}\in\mathbb{R}^{d} is said to be an œµitalic-œµ\epsilon-optimal first-order stationary point (œµitalic-œµ\epsilon-FOSP) if ‚Äñ‚àáf‚Äã(ùê±)‚Äñ‚â§œµnorm‚àáùëìùê±italic-œµ\left\|{\nabla f(\bm{x})}\right\|\leq\epsilon.

Definition 4.2.

Suppose that ùê±‚àà‚Ñùdùê±superscript‚Ñùùëë\bm{x}\in\mathbb{R}^{d} is an œµitalic-œµ\epsilon-FOSP. Then, ùê±ùê±\bm{x} is said to be an œµitalic-œµ\epsilon-optimal second-order stationary point (œµitalic-œµ\epsilon-SOSP) if

‚àá2f‚Äã(ùíô)‚™∞‚àíœÅ‚Äãœµ‚ãÖùë∞.succeeds-or-equalssuperscript‚àá2ùëìùíô‚ãÖùúåitalic-œµùë∞\nabla^{2}f(\bm{x})\succeq-\sqrt{\rho\epsilon}\cdot\bm{I}.

Otherwise, ùê±ùê±\bm{x} is said to be an œµitalic-œµ\epsilon-strict saddle point.

Moreover, we denote œá2:=œÉ2‚Äãlog‚Å°d+r2assignsuperscriptùúí2superscriptùúé2ùëësuperscriptùëü2\chi^{2}:=\sigma^{2}\log d+r^{2} the effective variance of stochastic gradient and perturbation, and Œ¶Œ¶\Phi the initialization quality where

Œ¶=1n‚Äã‚àëi=1n‚Äñ‚àá~p‚Äãfi‚Äã(ùíô0)+ùùÉ0‚Äñ2+L~‚Äã[f‚Äã(ùíô0)‚àífmin].Œ¶1ùëõsuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëõsuperscriptnormsubscript~‚àáùëùsubscriptùëìùëñsubscriptùíô0subscriptùùÉ02~ùêødelimited-[]ùëìsubscriptùíô0subscriptùëì\Phi=\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}\left\|{\tilde{\nabla}_{p}f_{i}(\bm{x}_{0})+\bm{\xi}_{0}}\right\|^{2}+\tilde{L}\left[f(\bm{x}_{0})-f_{\min}\right].

We are now ready to state the main theorems.

First-order convergence guarantee.

Theorem 4.3 establishes that Power-EF converges with high probability to œµitalic-œµ\epsilon-FOSP.

Based on Theorem 4.3, it is now immediate to compute the gradient complexity and communication rounds of Power-EF to attain first-order optimality, given by the corollary below.

Corollary 4.4 (œµitalic-œµ\epsilon-FOSP complexity).

for some constants Œ∫T,Œ∫Œ∑,Œ∫p,Œ∫r>0subscriptùúÖùëásubscriptùúÖùúÇsubscriptùúÖùëùsubscriptùúÖùëü0\kappa_{T},\kappa_{\eta},\kappa_{p},\kappa_{r}>0, and the parameter ŒπùúÑ\iota controlling the tightness of the probability bound. Set ‚Ñê=ŒπŒ∑‚ÄãœÅ‚Äãœµ‚ÑêùúÑùúÇùúåitalic-œµ\mathcal{I}=\frac{\iota}{\eta\sqrt{\rho\epsilon}}. Then, with probability at least 1‚àí8‚ÄãT2‚Äã(‚Ñê2+d‚Äã‚Ñê+‚Ñê+T)‚Äãe‚àíŒπ18superscriptùëá2superscript‚Ñê2ùëë‚Ñê‚ÑêùëásuperscriptùëíùúÑ1-8T^{2}(\mathcal{I}^{2}+d\mathcal{I}+\mathcal{I}+T)e^{-\iota}, at least half of the iterates {ùê±t}t=0Tsuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptùê±ùë°ùë°0ùëá\{\bm{x}_{t}\}_{t=0}^{T} generated by Algorithm 1 are œµitalic-œµ\epsilon-SOSPs.

Unlike Theorem¬†4.3, perturbing the local stochastic gradient with an appropriate radius plays a vital part in the second-order guarantee by assisting the iterates to escape the saddle points. Again, we can compute the gradient complexity and communication rounds of Power-EF to attain second-order optimality, given as follows.

Corollary 4.6 (œµitalic-œµ\epsilon-SOSP complexity).

Under the same setting of Theorem 4.5, Algorithm 1 requires O~‚Äã(1n‚Äãœµ4+1Œº1.5‚Äãœµ3+Œº‚Äãn+1Œº3‚Äãœµ2.5)~ùëÇ1ùëõsuperscriptitalic-œµ41superscriptùúá1.5superscriptitalic-œµ3ùúáùëõ1superscriptùúá3superscriptitalic-œµ2.5\tilde{O}\Big{(}\frac{1}{n\epsilon^{4}}+\frac{1}{\mu^{1.5}\epsilon^{3}}+\frac{\mu n+1}{\mu^{3}\epsilon^{2.5}}\Big{)} queries to the stochastic gradient oracle and communication rounds.

According to the corollaries, Power-EF improves to second-order stationary points after visiting first-order (possibly saddle) points, using additional gradient queries and communication rounds only of almost the same order required by first-order convergence when œµitalic-œµ\epsilon is typically small to be the dominant parameter. Contrary to another work allowing heterogeneous data (Fatkhullin et¬†al.,, 2021), our convergence rate exhibits a linear speedup in terms of nùëõn, implying that our algorithm significantly benefits from the distributed framework.

5 Numerical Experiments

In this section, we present the performance of Power-EF in distributed learning experiments to validate its efficiency empirically. We train a ResNet18 model on CIFAR10 dataset (Krizhevsky and Hinton,, 2009) using 4 clients and 1 server and compare the performance of various distributed optimization algorithms in the training task, including standard distributed SGD, SGD with naive compression, standard EF, and Power-EF. All the training procedures take 100 epochs with a step size of 10‚àí2superscript10210^{-2} and weight decay of 10‚àí4superscript10410^{-4}. For communication compression, we use Top-kùëòk compressor that keeps top 1% coordinates of the largest magnitudes, and Power-EF is tested with exponent p=1,4,8ùëù148p=1,4,8 respectively. The algorithms are implemented on PyTorch (Paszke et¬†al.,, 2019) 2.0.0 and the experiments are conducted on NVIDIA Tesla P100 GPU.

We summarize the results in Figure 1. According to Figure 1(a) and 1(b), without the feedback mechanism, the lossy compression significantly hinders the the convergence speed and prediction accuracy. On the other hand, EF and Power-EF have a comparable performance in boosting the training procedure and improving the accuracy. According to Figure 1(a), increasing the FCC parameter pùëùp, the convergence speed is almost not affected while an improved test loss is obtained in the final stage. A comparison between the communication efficiency of different algorithms is drawn in Figure 1(c). The compressor remarkably scales down the communication cost of the training procedure, from nearly 104superscript10410^{4} GB to no more than 102superscript10210^{2} GB for 100 epochs.

6 Conclusion

In this paper, we propose and analyze Power-EF, which is the first distributed SGD algorithm with communication compression that provably attains second-order optimality under heterogeneous data, to the best of our knowledge. Specifically, subject to mild and standard assumptions, we show that Power-EF converges to œµitalic-œµ\epsilon-SOSPs with high probability, which is almost on par with the gradient and communication complexity it takes to find œµitalic-œµ\epsilon-FOSPs, and the convergence rate shows a linear speedup with respect to nùëõn. Our theory are complemented by the performance of Power-EF in the distributed learning experiments. For future work, it will be of great interest to develop privacy-preserving distributed SGD algorithms that can escape saddle points with communication compression.

Proposition A.3 (Lemma 36, Jin et¬†al., (2021)).

‚Äñ‚àëi=1nùëøi‚Äñ2‚â§c‚ÄãœÉ2‚Äãn‚ÄãŒπsuperscriptnormsuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëõsubscriptùëøùëñ2ùëêsuperscriptùúé2ùëõùúÑ\left\|{\sum_{i=1}^{n}\bm{X}_{i}}\right\|^{2}\leq c\sigma^{2}n\iota

with probability at least 1‚àí2‚Äãd‚Äãe‚àíŒπ12ùëësuperscriptùëíùúÑ1-2de^{-\iota}.

With this, we can show that the global, accumulated stochastic gradient is a better estimator of the global true gradient, compared with each local stochastic gradient estimating its own true gradient.

Corollary A.4 (Global stochastic gradient noise).

Under Assumption 2.5, there exists a constant cùëêc such that the global stochastic gradient noise ùõátsubscriptùõáùë°\bm{\zeta}_{t} is a zero-mean nSG(c‚ÄãœÉ‚Äãlog‚Å°dn‚Äãp)ùëêùúéùëëùëõùëù\left(c\sigma\sqrt{\frac{\log d}{np}}\right) random vector.

Appendix B Proof of First-order Convergence

In this section we detail the proof of Theorem 4.3, a first-order convergence guarantee for Power-EF. To this end, we first provide a bound for the compression error ‚ÄñùíÜt‚Äñ2superscriptnormsubscriptùíÜùë°2\left\|{\bm{e}_{t}}\right\|^{2} (Lemma B.2), which supports an argument (Lemma B.3) that controls the true gradient norm of the iterates produced by Power-EF. Finally, an appropriate choice of parameters leads Lemma B.3 to the desired Theorem 4.3.

B.1 Compression error bound

We will use the following two lemmas to bound ‚ÄñùíÜt‚Äñ2superscriptnormsubscriptùíÜùë°2\left\|{\bm{e}_{t}}\right\|^{2}. The first lemma controls ‚Äñùíôt+1‚àíùíôt‚Äñ2superscriptnormsubscriptùíôùë°1subscriptùíôùë°2\left\|{\bm{x}_{t+1}-\bm{x}_{t}}\right\|^{2}, that is the difference between two consecutive iterates; the second technical lemma upper bounds a useful linear recurrence relation.

Lemma B.2 (Sum of compression error).

We are now ready to establish the desired result regarding the convergence to œµitalic-œµ\epsilon-FOSPs.

Proof of Theorem 4.3.

Otherwise, at least a quarter of the iterates have gradient norm larger than œµitalic-œµ\epsilon. Hence

‚àëœÑ=0T‚àí1‚Äñ‚àáf‚Äã(ùíôœÑ)‚Äñ2>T4‚Äãœµ2.superscriptsubscriptùúè0ùëá1superscriptnorm‚àáùëìsubscriptùíôùúè2ùëá4superscriptitalic-œµ2\sum_{\tau=0}^{T-1}\left\|{\nabla f(\bm{x}_{\tau})}\right\|^{2}>\frac{T}{4}\epsilon^{2}.

However, taking our choice of Œ∑ùúÇ\eta and TùëáT into Lemma B.3, the following holds with probability at least 1‚àí7‚Äãe‚àíŒπ17superscriptùëíùúÑ1-7e^{-\iota}:

‚àëœÑ=0T‚àí1‚Äñ‚àáf‚Äã(ùíôœÑ)‚Äñ2‚â§T‚Äãœµ2‚Äã(8Œ∫T+2‚Äãc‚ÄãŒ∫Œ∑2+2‚Äãc‚ÄãŒ∫Œ∑+cŒ∫T).superscriptsubscriptùúè0ùëá1superscriptnorm‚àáùëìsubscriptùíôùúè2ùëásuperscriptitalic-œµ28subscriptùúÖùëá2ùëêsuperscriptsubscriptùúÖùúÇ22ùëêsubscriptùúÖùúÇùëêsubscriptùúÖùëá\sum_{\tau=0}^{T-1}\left\|{\nabla f(\bm{x}_{\tau})}\right\|^{2}\leq T\epsilon^{2}\left(\frac{8}{\kappa_{T}}+2c\kappa_{\eta}^{2}+2c\kappa_{\eta}+\frac{c}{\kappa_{T}}\right). (16)

When we set Œ∫T‚â•8‚Äã(c+8)subscriptùúÖùëá8ùëê8\kappa_{T}\geq 8(c+8) and Œ∫Œ∑‚â§132‚ÄãcsubscriptùúÖùúÇ132ùëê\kappa_{\eta}\leq\frac{1}{32c}, (16) implies ‚àëœÑ=0T‚àí1‚Äñ‚àáf‚Äã(ùíôœÑ)‚Äñ2‚â§T‚Äãœµ2/4superscriptsubscriptùúè0ùëá1superscriptnorm‚àáùëìsubscriptùíôùúè2ùëásuperscriptitalic-œµ24\sum_{\tau=0}^{T-1}\left\|{\nabla f(\bm{x}_{\tau})}\right\|^{2}\leq T\epsilon^{2}/4, which produces a contradiction. ‚àé

Appendix C Proof of Second-order Convergence

The core idea for establishing the second-order convergence result (Theorem 4.5) is to show that, when Power-EF encounters a saddle point, the objective can still descend sufficiently after finitely many additional iterations (Lemma C.10).

Two arguments are developed to support this favorable property of Power-EF dynamics. Firstly, we show an improve-or-localize behavior of Power-EF (Lemma C.3): if the iterates {ùíöt}subscriptùíöùë°\{\bm{y}_{t}\} escape (move far enough) from a saddle point, the objective must descend sufficiently.

Secondly, we claim that the iterates do escape from saddle points (Corollary C.9). This nontrivial claim is obtained using the coupling sequences technique. To be specific, we craft another sequence {ùíöt‚Ä≤}subscriptsuperscriptùíö‚Ä≤ùë°\{\bm{y}^{\prime}_{t}\} mirroring the original iterates {ùíöt}subscriptùíöùë°\{\bm{y}_{t}\} along the escape direction of a saddle point. We show that the gap between the coupling sequences ‚Äñùíöt‚àíùíöt‚Ä≤‚Äñnormsubscriptùíöùë°subscriptsuperscriptùíö‚Ä≤ùë°\left\|{\bm{y}_{t}-\bm{y}^{\prime}_{t}}\right\| expands sufficiently after finitely many iterations (Lemma C.8), which implies {ùíöt}subscriptùíöùë°\{\bm{y}_{t}\} travels far from the saddle point.

This workflow of establishing second-order convergence guarantees stems from pioneering works on plain GD and SGD (Jin et¬†al.,, 2017, 2021), and finds similar applications in several recent works such as recursive SGD (Li,, 2019), and compressed SGD (Avdiukhin and Yaroslavtsev,, 2021). While the theory in Avdiukhin and Yaroslavtsev, (2021) entails respective discussions on the large-gradient case and small-gradient case, Power-EF avoids such intricacies due to the technical fact that our bound for ùíÜtsubscriptùíÜùë°\bm{e}_{t} does not involve gradient norm terms.

For conciseness, we presume the following parameter setting for our theory and do not restate them therein.

Proposition C.5 (Proposition B.12, Avdiukhin and Yaroslavtsev, (2021)).

For any tùë°t, it holds that

where

According to Proposition C.5, ùíö^t0+tsubscript^ùíösubscriptùë°0ùë°\hat{\bm{y}}_{t_{0}+t} decomposes into a sum of four terms, each showing the effect of one type of quantity that acumulates with time. Actually one can observe that ùö´tsubscriptùö´ùë°\bm{\Delta}_{t} reflects a cumulative dynamics of {ùíôt0+t}subscriptùíôsubscriptùë°0ùë°\{\bm{x}_{t_{0}+t}\} and {ùíôt0+t‚Ä≤}subscriptsuperscriptùíô‚Ä≤subscriptùë°0ùë°\{\bm{x}^{\prime}_{t_{0}+t}\}, ùë¨t+Œ∑‚ÄãùíÜ^t0+tsubscriptùë¨ùë°ùúÇsubscript^ùíÜsubscriptùë°0ùë°\bm{E}_{t}+\eta\hat{\bm{e}}_{t_{0}+t} a cumulative compression error, ùíÅtsubscriptùíÅùë°\bm{Z}_{t} a cumulative stochastic gradient noise, and ùöµtsubscriptùöµùë°\bm{\Xi}_{t} a cumulative artificial perturbation.

In order to bound ùíö^t0+tsubscript^ùíösubscriptùë°0ùë°\hat{\bm{y}}_{t_{0}+t}, it is then a natural choice to bound each of the components respectively.

Lemma C.6 (Cumulative error bound).

Suppose that Assumption 2.1*, 2.2, 2.5 hold. There exists a constant cùëêc such that with probability at least 1‚àí12‚Äãt‚Äãe‚àíŒπ112ùë°superscriptùëíùúÑ1-12te^{-\iota},

‚Äñùë¨t+Œ∑‚ÄãùíÜ^t0+t‚Äñ‚â§c‚ÄãL‚ÄãŒ∑Œ≥‚ÄãŒ¶+œá2‚ÄãŒπŒº2‚Äãn‚Äãp‚Äã(1+Œ∑‚ÄãŒ≥)t.normsubscriptùë¨ùë°ùúÇsubscript^ùíÜsubscriptùë°0ùë°ùëêùêøùúÇùõæŒ¶superscriptùúí2ùúÑsuperscriptùúá2ùëõùëùsuperscript1ùúÇùõæùë°\left\|{\bm{E}_{t}+\eta\hat{\bm{e}}_{t_{0}+t}}\right\|\leq\frac{cL\eta}{\gamma}\sqrt{\Phi+\frac{\chi^{2}\iota}{\mu^{2}np}}(1+\eta\gamma)^{t}.
Proof.

Lemma C.7 (Artificial noise dynamics).

For any tùë°t, there exists a constant cùëêc such that

‚Äñùöµt‚Äñ‚â§c‚ÄãŒπ‚ÄãŒ∑‚Äãr2‚Äãn‚Äãp‚ÄãŒ≥‚Äãd‚Äã(1+Œ∑‚ÄãŒ≥)tnormsubscriptùöµùë°ùëêùúÑùúÇùëü2ùëõùëùùõæùëësuperscript1ùúÇùõæùë°\left\|{\bm{\Xi}_{t}}\right\|\leq\frac{c\sqrt{\iota\eta}r}{\sqrt{2np\gamma d}}(1+\eta\gamma)^{t}

‚Äñùöµt‚Äñ‚â•Œ∑‚Äãr3‚Äã6‚Äãn‚Äãp‚ÄãŒ≥‚Äãd‚Äã(1+Œ∑‚ÄãŒ≥)tnormsubscriptùöµùë°ùúÇùëü36ùëõùëùùõæùëësuperscript1ùúÇùõæùë°\left\|{\bm{\Xi}_{t}}\right\|\geq\frac{\sqrt{\eta}r}{3\sqrt{6np\gamma d}}(1+\eta\gamma)^{t}

with probability at least 2323\frac{2}{3}.

Proof.

This is a direct extension of Lemma 30, Jin et¬†al., (2021). ‚àé

Lemma C.8 (Coupling sequence dynamics).

Suppose that Assumption 2.1*, 2.2, 2.3, 2.5 hold, and

max‚Å°{‚Äñùíöt0+t‚àíùíöt0‚Äñ,‚Äñùíöt0+t‚Ä≤‚àíùíöt0‚Äñ}‚â§‚Ñõ‚àÄt‚â§‚Ñê.formulae-sequencenormsubscriptùíösubscriptùë°0ùë°subscriptùíösubscriptùë°0normsubscriptsuperscriptùíö‚Ä≤subscriptùë°0ùë°subscriptùíösubscriptùë°0‚Ñõfor-allùë°‚Ñê\max\{\left\|{\bm{y}_{t_{0}+t}-\bm{y}_{t_{0}}}\right\|,\left\|{\bm{y}^{\prime}_{t_{0}+t}-\bm{y}_{t_{0}}}\right\|\}\leq\mathcal{R}\quad\forall t\leq\mathcal{I}.

Proof.

From Lemma C.8, we observe that the difference between the coupling sequences has an exponential growth with time tùë°t, under the assumption that the iterates get stuck around the saddle points. Intuitively, after a sufficiently long period, it is contradictory to grow exponentailly and remain stuck at the same time. We now validate this intuition and show that the iterates generated by Power-EF is able to escape the saddle points.

Corollary C.9 (Escaping saddle points).

Suppose that Assumption 2.1*, 2.2, 2.3, 2.5 hold. Then with probability at least 13‚àí‚Ñê‚Äã(6‚Äã‚Ñê+2‚Äãd+1)‚Äãe‚àíŒπ13‚Ñê6‚Ñê2ùëë1superscriptùëíùúÑ\frac{1}{3}-\mathcal{I}(6\mathcal{I}+2d+1)e^{-\iota},

C.4 Convergence

Combining Corollary C.9 with the improve-or-localize behavior of Power-EF (Lemma C.3), we conclude that the objective receives sufficient descent.

Lemma C.10 (Descent from saddles).

Suppose that Assumption 2.1*, 2.2, 2.3, 2.5 hold. Then with probability at least 1‚àí7‚Äã‚Ñê‚Äãe‚àíŒπ17‚ÑêsuperscriptùëíùúÑ1-7\mathcal{I}e^{-\iota},

We arrive at the final stage to show the convergence to œµitalic-œµ\epsilon-SOSPs.

Proof of Theorem 4.5.

All the iterates can be classified into three types, namely (i) iterates that are not œµitalic-œµ\epsilon-FOSPs, (ii) œµitalic-œµ\epsilon-strict saddle points, and (iii) œµitalic-œµ\epsilon-SOSPs. By Theorem 4.3, we have showed that at most 1/4 of the iterates are not œµitalic-œµ\epsilon-FOSPs. Therefore, it suffices to show that at most 1/4 of the iterates are œµitalic-œµ\epsilon-strict saddle points.
